January 14, 1958
Dr* Harry J. Skornia, Executive Director,
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
14 Gregory Hall
Urban*, XUinois
Dear Doctor Skornia,
Tour letter of January 2 was shared by a number of us at Motorola and
1 thank you for it. Its message was reassuring; it gave promise of
action in areas that need development.
News releases of the past few weeks on the proposals for federal aid to
education have been disturbing. No mention is being made of the use of
television or radio as aids in making up for lost time in certain subject
areas. Instead, an i nadequale and slow moving program of scholarships
has been suggested. This to my thinking, is like going back to the horse
and buggy for transportation at a time when we hare jet planes at our
disposal.
In following the accounts of business conducted by the Association of
American Colleges in its meeting in Miami last week, there was
additional disappointment. Apparently the time given over to the bitter
debate on federal aid precluded any significant consideration of the use
of new methods for instruction.
These situations do bother me; and I am certain they are cause for comment
and concern by people like you. In a country familiar with the techniques
of heavy voiced lobbies 1 am wondering whether the individual voices of
NAJEB, JCET, CET, and the E1A { Our own industrial group - formerly
RJCTMAi have been heard at all!
